Taking it on trust: Form and meaning in naturalistic representation. Arch. Natur. Hist., 1990, 17: 127-188. "I intend to look at two major episodes in the intersect- ing histories of natural history and art. What I will be doing is studying how the techniques of naturalism were actually used at different times, rather than assuming that naturalistic illustrations were to be 'seen' in the same functional way as we would view them today. The two episodes concern what I will firstly call the construction of the treasure-house of natural curiosities-covering the period from the Middle Ages to the 17th century-and secondly, the motif of the fight for survival in the natural jungle as developed in the 18th and 19th centuries. I do not pre- tend that describing these episodes will explain the motive 24</page><page sequence="25">24c. Biological Sciences: Zoology forces at the centre of the histories of natural history and art, but I think they will show that the interaction of form and meaning at the interfaces between the worlds of the scientist and artist needs to be reassessed." 380 Moore, James R. "This paper investigates the epistemic achievements of technical simulation providing explanations for non- technical systems. It aims to show that there exist simu- lations whose simulators and explananda are identical that provide nevertheless different explanations, presenting as an example the simulation of living systems by gear wheel mechanisms in the biology of Aristotle and Descartes." "Ambiguous sigils or carecters are commonly found in late-medieval English texts on magic, alchemy, weights and measurement, astronomy and astrology, and medical reme- dies. They appear in the context of Latin, English, and mixed-language texts, and an analysis of these carecters used by authors and scribes instead of words reveals much about the nature of the texts and about the languages of the era." 999 Vossenkuhl, Wilhelm; Schonberger, Rolf (eds.) II ruolo della tecnica nella nascita della scienza moderna. Cult. Scu., 1989, 28(109): 202-209. 1339 Pinto, John. The Renaissance city image. Pp. 205-254 in A.C. Crombie, Nancy Siraisi (eds.) The rational arts of living. Northamp- ton, Mass.: Dept. of History, Smith College, 1987. "An examination of the origin and the specific characteris- tics of the ichnographic city plan underscores a remarkable similarity of method and intention among a number of examples which are generally considered only in isolation. The study of ichnographic city plans and their relation to the development of 16th-century surveying techniques enhances our understanding of an especially significant branch of Renaissance cartography and related aspects of military and urban planning. Moreover, such a study pro- vides a specific example of the application of scientific empirircism and technology to the formulation of new conceptual and representational modes in the Renaissance." 1340 Ricossa, Sergio (ed.) Le macchine di Valturio, nei documenti dell'archivio storico Amma. 175 pp., illus., notes, index. Torino: Allemandi, 1988. "By analyzing the dialogue (or rather lack of it) between Galileo and the Tuscan Aristotelians during the debate on buoyancy in 1611-13, I want to argue that incommen- surability between competing paradigms is not just an unfortunate problem of linguistic communication, but it plays an important role in the process of scientific change and paradigm-speciation." 1517 Biagioli, Mario. An iconographical riddle: Ger- brandt van den Eeckhout's Royal repast in the Liechtenstein Princely Collections. Art Bull., 1989, 71: 611-627. Provides an alchemical interpretation of Eeckhout's paint- ing. "Eeckhout's iconography comes from popular alchem- ical emblem books and from medieval sources that were reprinted in the 17th century in response to a renewed fascination with early alchemical imagery. The Royal Repast not only reflects the 17th-century percpetion of alchemy as a force for the public good, but also demon- strates that the history of chemistry is a relatively unex- plored area for art-historical research in Dutch 17th-century painting." 1679 Dobbs, Betty Jo Teeter. Berlin: Schmidt, 1987. 1778 Schaffer, Simon. Defoe's natural philos- ophy and the worlds of credit. Pp. 13-44 in John Christie, Sally Shuttleworth (eds.) Nature transfigured: Science and literature, 1700- 1900. Manchester: Manchester Univ. Press, 1989. "This chapter examines the career of Daniel Defoe, whose texts seem to infringe the boundaries of fictional, natural philosophical and journalistic disciplines. This examination does not assume the self-evident authority of the 'scien- tific' at this conjuncture. On the contrary, it focuses on the ways in which different techniques and communities made different claims for control over natural and social milieux. Rival claims to such worlds involved the cate- gory of credit. Credit stood for the new authority of the autonomous reporter and experimenter, and, at the same time, for the new social relations between the stockholder and the merchant." 1779 Schlieben-Lange, Brigitte (ed.) From 1702 to 1708 Psalmanazar presented himself to the British intelligentsia as a For- mosan pagan, converted to Christianity, and he wrote a widely accepted 'Historical and Geographical Description' of his 'native' country. I will claim that the aberration Psalmanazar poses in the description of otherness is an aberration that is nonethless typical of a period in which the claims of writing-the claims of authorship, original- ity, genius, and documentation-were in tremendous flux. In looking at the historical conditions of Psalmanazar's writing we find a problematic of artifice and authenticity that speaks particularly to ethnography's current self- consciousness regarding its roots in rhetoric as well as its roots in ethnology." 2030 Sumser, Robert M. Context, 1988, 2: 115-145. "It is often assumed that all sciences travel the path of increasing precision and quantificaiton. It is also assumed that such processes transcend the boundaries of rival sci- entific disciplines. The history of the personal equation has been cited as an example: the 'personal equation' was the name given by astronomers after Bessel to the differences in measured transit times recorded by observers in the same situation. Later in the 19th century Wilehlm Wundt used this phenomenon as a type for his experi- ments on reaction times. For historians of psychology, this has been taken to be an exemplary case where quantified laboratory science rescued astronomy by showing that this was really a psychological phenomenon measurable only in complication experiments. This paper challenges this story." 2367 Schaffer, Simon. The nebular hypothe- sis and the science of progress. Pp. 131-164 in James R. Moore (ed.) History, humanity, and evolution: Essays for John C. Greene. Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1989. Examines the nebular hypothesis in Victorian Britain in its sense as a "general model of the universal progressive de- velopment shown in the heavens, on Earth and in human society". Instruments on the cusp of science and technology: The Indicator dia- gram. Knowl. Soc., 1989, 8: 107-122. The Indicator diagram is an instrument attached to the working cylinder of a heat engine to measure the amount of work extracted from the heat energy run through the engine. This paper traces the history of the Indicator from its invention by James Watt and John Southern in the 1790s to its role in Emile Clapeyron's (1834) contribution to the newly-developing science of thermodynamics. 2841 Baroncini, Gabriele. Mapping experiment as a learning process: How the first electromag- netic motor was invented. Sci. Technol. Hum. Val., 1990, 15: 165-201. "Narrative accounts misrepresent discovery by reconstruct- ing worlds ordered by success rather than the world as explored. Such worlds rarely contain the personal knowl- edge that informed actual exploration and experiment. This article describes an attempt to recover situated learning in a material environment, tracing the discovery of the first electromagnetic motor by Michael Faraday in Septem- ber 1821 to show how he modeled new experience and invented procedures to communicate that novelty." 2872 Gorman, Michael E.; Carlson, W. Bernard. Interpreting invention as a cogni- tive process: The case of Alexander Graham Bell, Thomas Edison, and the telephone. Sci. Technol. Hum. Val., 1990, 15: 131-164. "Historians of technology have provided important accounts of technological innovation, but they rarely employ con- cepts which permit a rigorous analysis of invention as a mental or cognitive process. This article seeks to address this theoretical lacuna by using concepts adapted form cog- nitive psychology to compare the mental processes of two telephone inventors, Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas Edison." 2873 Greenberg, Dolores. Mediating machines. Sci. Context, 1988, 2: 77-113. "The societal context within which science is pursued generally acts as a productive force in the generation of knowledge. To analyze this action it is helpful to consider particular modes of mediation through which societal concerns are projected into the very local and esoteric concers of a particular domain of research. One such mode of mediation occurs through material systems. Here I treat two such systems-the steam engine and the electric telegraph-in the natural philosophy of William Thomson (Lord Kelvin)." 2935 Wrigley, E.A. (eds.) 50 years with nuclear fission, Na- tional Academy of Sciences, Washington, D.C. and National Institute of Standards and Tech- nology, Gaithersburg, Maryland, April 25-28, 1989. 2 vols., xv + 978 pp., illus., notes, in- dex. La Grange Park, Ill.: American Nuclear Society, 1989. 3049 Beller, Mara. Experimental accuracy, operationalism, and the limits of knowledge, 1925 to 1935. Sci. Context, 1988, 2: 147- 162. "This paper analyzes the complex and many-layered in- terrelation between the realization of the inevitable limits of precision in the experimental domain, the emerging quantum theory, and empirically oriented philosophy in the years 1925-1935. In contrast to the usual historical pre- sentation of Heisenberg's uncertainty principle as a purely theoretical achievment, this work discloses the experimental roots of Heisenberg's contribution. In addition, this paper argues that the positivistic philosophy of elimination of unobservables was not used as a guiding principle in the emergence of the new quantum theory, but rather mostly as a post facto justification. The case of P.W. Bridgman, analyzed in this paper, demonstrates how inconclusive operationalistic arguments are, when used as a possible heuristic aid for future discoveries. A large part of this paper is devoted to the evolution of Bridgman's views, and his skeptical reassessment of operationalism and of the very notion of scientific truth." 3050 Ben-Menahem, Yemima. Struggling with causality: Schrodinger's case. Stud. Hist. Phil. Sci., 1989, 20: 307-334. 3051 Berger, Gabriel. Mir langt's, ich gehe: Der Lebensweg eines DDR-Atomphysikers von Anpassung zu Aufruhr. Hunt (University of Warwick) Review Editor L.J. Bennett The British Journal for the Philosophy of Science has, since 1951, established itself as the leading international journal in its field. It aims to study the logic, method, and philosophy of science as well as the various special sciences including the social sciences. In addition it publishes extended review articles of important books - or groups of books on related topics - as well as encouraging correspondence and discussion of previously published articles. The Journal is the official organ of the British Society for the Philosophy of Science. Recent and forthcoming articles include: The Many Faces of Irreversibility; Perception and Neuroscience; Structural Analogies between Physical Systems; The New Experimentalism; The Metaphysics of the Social World; Inference, Learning and Discovery; Economics and Metaphysics; Zande Logic and Western Logic; Spin and Relativity; Aesthetic Constraints on Theory Choice; Is the Universe Causally Closed?; Mathematics and Darwinism; Modularity of Mind Revisited. |l||| |Subscription Rates for Volume 41, 1990 : ....Non-Members UK ?23, E.C ?27, N.A5,.El *Mem bers UK?14, EEC?15, N.Am a US$ 0, Elsew * For details of membership to the Society please write to Membership Secretary, British Society for the Philosphy Science c/o Oxford University Press at the address below.
